div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

Hall's Sanitary Washable Distemper
div.p: Made in 70 Colors
An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL'S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL'S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration.

HALL'S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. Owing to its cool, pleasing colours, great weather-resisting and germ-destroying properties, it lends itself to every kind of wall, wood, brick or stone coating, possessing all the advantages of paint, colour- wash, and disinfectant at one third the cost of oil paint. It never blisters in the hottest sun, and the fact that it can be washed adds greatly to its sanitary advantages.
Supplied in Tins and Iron Kegs.
Sole Manufacturers :
SISSONS BROTHERS & CO., LTD., HULL.
Stocks are held In Cairo by Frank Ratcliffe, Sanitary Contractor and Engineer, Sharia Saptieh.

THURSDAY; OCTOBER 19.
JAPAN'S NAVAL POWER.

With the refloating of the Pobyeda— whose time by a strange irony of fate means ' Vict- ory"—the last of the font great ironclads which were sunk within Port Arthur harbour set December has been added to the fleet of the cocquering islanders. It was at first sup- osed that the Pobyeds and her comrades in misfortune were injured beyond all hope of repair by the explosion of Russian dynamite mines as much as by the shimose shells hurled on them by the artillery of the investing force. Recent investigations hate proved that his is not the case. The engines of all, or nearly all, the sunken ships had been grossed and the valves opened, and though the I droppiog shells from the land batteries had done them a certain amount of damage, the nines had only been need in the last few hours, when the intention *of General Stoessel to surrender had astonished and horrified Capt. Wiren and driven the undemoralised remnants of the fleet to attempt to destroy heir own ships. It appears that these vessels had been sunk in the first instance with the view of preserving them till Rodjestveosky's arrival in Eastern wafers. Their engines, etc., had been greased, their guns and ammuni- ion for the most part removed to shore, and the Rossians counted on being able to raise their vessels after Rodjestvensky had fought a fleet action, in February, which they expected would prove sufficiently destructive to both sides, and to thrown few "lame docks" into the balance of the naval war. They count- td, of course, on the Baltic Fleet arriving in February and on its being far more battle worthy than it ultimately proved, and their chagrin at Stoossel's sudden surrender cost have been profound.

Japan had now added eight Russian iron- clads to her fleet, and thorgh experts have declared that four of the captured vessels will lever be fit for much, the fact that the Japanese have been at pains to raise and repair them goes far to prove that they are better informed of the real condition of the hulls than their critics. The Mikasa will probably be raised in a couple of months' time add Japan will then have thirteen battleship*, four of them old and second line vessels, and right large armoured cruisers that hare proved themselves capable of lying in the line. Two very powerful battle- ships and two large armoured cruisers are building, and though no indemnity has been obtained, there is every reason to expect that the new programme spoken of early in the was will be carried out in the next five or six years Japan is now fifth in the list of the naval Powers, as far as her material strength is concerned, bat we imagine that when the experience of her sailors, and the practical training of her gunners, is taken into account no judge of comparative naval strength will refuse a still higher place to the naval forces of the Risen Sun.

div.head:
LONDON'S NEW STREETS
ROYAL OPENING
PARIS MUNICIPALITY HONORES

div.p: Their Majesties the King and Queen have opened Kingsway and Aldwych. The weather was beautiful. The members of the Paris Municipality occupied front seats, and their Majesties shook hands with the president. Three addresses were presented, including one from the popular party, dealing with the ques- tion of the unemployed, but no deputation of the unemployed was received.
The Lord Mayor entertained the members of the Paris Municipality at luncheon at the Mansion House. The most cordial toasts were exchanged. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE MULLAH AGAIN
CAUSING TROUBLE TO ITALIANS

div.p: The Mullah is causing trouble in the Italian spere in Somaliland. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SORROWS OF ARMENIA
TERRIBLE STITUATION

div.p: The Armenian Archimandrite has reported to the Viceroy of the Caucasus that ten Arme- nian villages have been plundered and that the situation of the inhabitants is terrible. Robber bands are desolating the country. Pacification is impossible. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE MOROCCO INCIDENT.
ENGLISH OFFICERS STILL PRISONERS

div.p: The "Daily Mail" learns from Madrid that the Moors, fearing an attack from the British toro do-boats, have released Captain Crowther and Lieutenant Hutton, who have arrived at Centa.
The Moors fired on H.M.S. destroyer Cherwell near Ceuts. Some bullets pierced her found. (Reuter)
Captain Crowther and Lieutenant Hutton are still prisoned. (Reuter)

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY.
THE NATION AND THE CROWN

div.p: The King, on appointing Court Fejervary president of the council, writes that the true meaning of his former declarations costi- tutes a complete agreement between the nation and the Crown, regarding the inde- pendence guaranteed by the constitution. (H)

div.head:
AMERICAN INSURANCE SCANDALS
MR. McCURDY'S ADMISSION

div.p: Mr. McCurdy, President of the Mutual Life, admitted that large sums have been paid to politicians for services. (Reuter)
Gen. Gallieni, Governor General of Madagas- car, has tendered his resignation. (Reuter)
General Gallieni, Governor of Madagascar, has resigned. M. Augagneur will probably succeed him. (Havas)
Submarine at has been dry-docked. (R.)

div.head: ERRATUM
div.p: We are informed that the note on Tor Lighthouse which we published on Tuesday in our Port Said correspondent's notes refers to the new lighthouse at Sanganeib.

div.head: STRAY DOGS
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Darb el-Ahmar district of Cairo during the night of Friday will be poisoned by the police.
RAILWAY COAL CONTRACT
The Egyptian State Rail contract for 210,000 tons of Watts, Milburn, and Company, of Cardiff, at 11s. 3d. per ton f.o.b.
OMDER SENTENCED

Our Tahta corrspon- dent writes that the Tahta Summary Court had before it last week a civil case in which the Omdeh of Nag-Hawadi was one of the witnesses for defense. The Tribunal noticing an obvious ontradiction in the evid- ence given by the Omdeh and his two friends, and being convinced of their being perjurors, sentenced each to 4 months imprisonment.
PLAYING WITH FIRE

A native boy of 6, names Nasr- Eddeen, was playing with his little sister before their house in Alexandria when another little girl of 7 years, names Sessouteh Bessyouni, came up and flunge a light- ed match at the boy. The child's clothes caught fire and his companions were unable to ex- tigerish it. The unfortunate boy received such terrible injuries that he succumbed a few hours later.
TRAMCAR COLLISION IN CAIRO

Traincar No. 36 collided yesterday morning with a cart laden with sand opposite the main entrance to Kasr el Nil barracks. The car was going at a fair speed and the cart was the time crossing the line. The car-driver rang his bell and shouted to the man to get out of way, but, to the astonishment of the lookers-on, did not slacken speed. The front board of the car be- came entangled with the axle pin of the cart and it was with considerable difficulty that the latter was extricated. Had the driver of the car exercised a certain amount of caution the collision might have easily been avoided.
MEHKEMEH PERSURES

Our Tahta Corres- spondent states that last Thursday a native of El Atamneh with his so-called daughter and two witnesses proceeded to the Mehkemeh Court to-draw up a "tawkil" on behalf of the girl. The Cadi asked the witnesses whether the woman was really the daughter of the claimant and received an affirmative reply, but after the tawkil had been granted the head fhaffir of El Atamneh appeare I before the Cadi and informed him that the girl was his own niece and not the daughter of the claimant. The guilty parties were arrested for impersonation and perjury.
MAP OF THE LEBANOS

We have received an interesting and well-executed map of the Lebanon district, the work of Major Huber, ex-engineer in chief to the province of the Lebanon. The map, which is drawn up on the scale of 1/100,000 is divided into four sheets and gives the principal churches, roads, and caracole of the province. The only criticism we have to make is the comparative absence of details as to the frontier districts N.E. of Zsh- leg, and in the N.E. of the Kara and Bastroun divisions, but the compiler's explanation that the boundaries of the province are still unde- termined no doubt accounts for this.
TO CONVERT THE JAPS

"Al Lewa" learns that Mullah Mirzakhan and Maulvi Ibrahim, two religious Mohamedans of India, recently resolved to leave for Japan to preach the Koran, in the hope of spreading Islam among the Japanese. Mr. Korima, the Japanese official appointed to make a study of the world's religions, has lately read a book on Islam written by a chinese Mohamedan, and a Japanese committee called the author and received him very cordially. In their religious conversation the stopped at the Mohamedan words "La ilaha ills Allah" (there is no God but the one God), when Mr. Korims exclaimed that there were several duties. The committee however, resolved that every Moslem rule which proved to be right and suitable should be inserted in the Japa- nese papers.

div.head: LORD CROMER RETURNS
div.p: HIS LORDSHIPS ARRIVAL AT CAIRO

As was announced in our issue of yesterday, Lord Cromer arrived at Port Said the day before and was attached to the train leaving at 8:10 am, his lordship preferring to travel by that train rather than wait for the midday express. The train arrived at Cairo punctually at 1.30 p.m. and Lord Cromer stepped from his carriage to be greated by the large crown of officials who had come to meet him and among whom we noticed H.E. Mustapha Pasha Febmy, President of the Council of Ministers, Sir Reginald F. Wingate Pasha, Sir Rudolf von Slatin Pasha Scandar Pasha Fehmy El Lewa Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, Mazloum Pasha, Fahkry Pasha, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mr. P W. Machell, Mr. M. de C. Findlay, C.M.G., Mr. A.D. Alban, Dr. Hayward, Major l'Estrange Johnstone, and many others.
After his lordship had shaken hands with everybody he drove direct to the British Agency. We are glad to be able to report that his lordship is looking in the best of health

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will proceed to Mansourah to-morrow to inaugurate the Mansourah agri- cultural show. The special Khedivial train will leave Montarah Palace station at 10 a.m. and will stop only at Sidi Gaber station, where the Ministers will meet his Highness and accompany him to Mansourah

As previously announced, the Khedive will attend Friday prayers at the Mahmoudieh Mosque. He will leave mansourah at 4 p.m. arriving at Montazah Palace at about 7 p.m. His Higness will preside over the inaugura- tion of the new filters, which will take place on Tuesday, 24th inst, at 4.30 p.m. at the Alexandria Water Company's buildings at the Rond Point.

div.head: Egyptian Options
div.p: We are informed that an expedition under the direction of Mr. Francis Merton, which left London via Brindis on the 13th inst. for Port Said, and which is accompanied by Mr. J. Morrow Campbell as assistant engineer, is about to prospect the properties of the Egypt- ian Options, Limited, extending over some 10,500 sq. miles of country, which is said to be situated in the auriferous territory, and where it is believed numerous old workings exist. They will proceed direct to Assouan on arrival in Egypt.
Mr. Waddington, jun, a son of one of the directors of the company, accompanies the expedition, which as arrived in Cairo.

div.head: ANTI-TURKIS PLOTS
div.p: "Al Mokattam" states that the Macedonian, Arab, Armenian, and Albanian Nationalist committee are about to hold a conference at Brussels at which Ism Bay Kamel and Neguib Bay Azoury will attend. The committees will agree on some common plan of action for their mutual benefit. It is to be hoped that, whatever decision they take, they will abstain from instigating fanatics to hurl bombs and excit- ing half civilized mobs to commit useless bar- barities.

div.head: SLEEPING CAR COMPANY
div.p: The Sleeping and Restaurant Car Company, under the able management of Mr. H.W. Tite, is making every arrangement to satisfy the large number of tourists who are expected during the coming season. All the sleeping cars have been almost entirely renewed inter- nally and no comfort has been forgotten. Two new restaurant cars have been ordered from Belgium and are expected to arrive here in December. The company have also arranged to open an agency at Assouan, similar to the one at Kuxor, for the sale of tickets and the general sub-management of the Assouan to Luxor line. An improvement in the Port Said passenger service was inaugurated on Tuesday by the running of a social train to Cairo immediatley after the arrival of the P. and O. Marseilles boat,for which an extra 20% on the price of the ticket is charged, but the charges for dinner and refreshments in the restaurant car remain the same as last winter; this special train will be continued as long as the traffic warrants it, and we understand that the Railway Adminis- triton will make similar arrangements on the Cairo-to-Luxor line should it be found advisa- ble. Such enterprise on the part of the Administration and the Sleeping Car Company should be warmly greeted by residents and tourists alike

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO
div.p: The management have, in response to a general request, again engaged the service of Count Bellini, the celebrated thought-reader, for a second seance on the terrace of the casino, on Saturday next at 9.30 pm. The Bracale orchestra will play during the evening, and on this occasion season tickets are sue- spended.
The following is the program me of the Bracale concert for to-morrow, commencing at 5.30 pm.

div.head:
A MAHARAJA AT PORT SAID
ON WAY TO MEET THE PRINCE
div.p: FROM OUT CORRESPONDENT
PORT SAID, Wednesday

The P and O mail boat, the S.S. Moldavia, arrived here yesterday at midday. Among the many passengers on board and I noticed the Maharaja of Takari, Mr. and Mrs. Geo Royle, and Mr. and Mrs. Snow Bey. The Maharaja of Takari has been visiting London and Paris and is now returning to India to welcome the Prince and Princess of Walce on their arrival there. During the stay the S.S. Moldavia made at Port Said, the Maharaja and suite and a party of friends dined at the Eastern Exchange, where they were met by a special courier, Angelo Zvzzers, who had come for the purpose from Bombay.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT
div.p: The battleship Renown left Portamouth on Sunday morning for Genoa to embark the Prince and Princess of Wales for their Indian trip. The first-class cruiser Terrible, which is to act as escort during the voyage, accompanied her. Some of the personal attendants and servants have gone on the Renown in order to make the necessary preparations for their Royal Highnesses, who, with their suite, em- bark at Genoa on the 19th inst. The renown leaves the Itallian port on the 21st inst. I hear from a reliable source that H.M.S. powerful and Terrible are expected to arrive here on the 24th inst. with Lord Shae. Bereford, and that the Renown will be accompanied by the Suffolk, Lancoster, and Cambrian, which are due to arrive here on the 26th inst., if the Prince and Princess leave Genoa at the appointed time. As I wired you to day, Lord Cromer arrived here tho morning by the Isia from Brindisi. His lordship was accompanied by Mr. Cameron, the British Consul at Port Said, who has been to England on leave.

div.head: FASHIONABLE WEDDING.
div.p: HERBERT-GORST

In St. Margaret's Church, Westminister, last week, Miss Gwendolen Goret, youngest daughter of the Right. Hon. Sir John Gorst, M.P. was married to Major Edward Sidney Herbert, of the Black Watch, at present attached to the Egyptian Army, the bride, who was given away by her father, wearing a gown of white monsseline de soie, over white satin, trimmed with old English point lace, while her toll veil was worn over a wreath of myrtle and white heather. Miss Eileen Gorst and Master Arobie Honter, niece and nephew of the bride, acted as train bearers, and Miss Gorst, her elder sister was bridesmaid. Captain Morant, Egyptian Army, accompanied by the bridegroom as best man, and the officiating energy were Canon Hensley Heuson, rector of St. Marga- ret's and the Rev. E. Otway Herbert, ounce of the bridegroom. Among the large con- gregation were the Earl of Cromer, Lady and Miss Grant, Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst, Lady and Miss Palmer, Sir Anthony Cope, the Hon. Mrs. Rees, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gorst, Mrs. Paston Cooper, Sir William and Lady Dick- Canyngham, Col Egerston, Col. Caldwell, and others. Lady Gorst afterwards held a reception at Queen Anne's Gate, and later in the day Major and Mrs. E.S. Herbert left for Castle Combe, lent them by Mr. E.C. Lowndes, the bride's uncle.

div.head: SUAKIN-ATBARA RAILWAY
div.p: It was officially announced yesterday that the last rails of the Suskin-Atbara Railway had been laid on the 13th inst. Our Suakin Correspondent, writing on the 4th inst. says:- Work at Railhand has been recommended as the washouts are over, and the lines are being rapidlyy pushed on. Several trains with material are leaving here daily for Railhead, so that in case of the line brewing they may have a stock of rails and sleepers to go on with. A few miles of rails have yet to be laid to complete the Suakin-Atbara Railway, but it is hoped to have the line ready in about a fortnight.
Colonel Macoulay Bey, R.E, Director of dirieh and the Sudan Railways have returned from their summer holidays. It is noticeable that a large number of them have brought their families with them.

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC
div.p: During the month of September 559,613 kilos of gum arabic, valued at LE 14,559, were exported from WEgypt. In the same month of 1904 the exports were 851.627 kilos, of the value of LE 19,162; a decrease in 1905 of 292,014 kilos, value LE 4,610.

From the 1st January to the 30th September, 1905, the exports to England and her Medi- terrane an possessions were 961,238 kilos, value L.E. 23,422; Germany 1,627,493 kilos, value L.E. 39,231; Austria-Hungary. 517,348 kilos, value L.E. 5,977; Turkey, 7,575 kilos, value L.E. 18; America 856,087 kilos, value L.E. 21,035; and to other countries 1,079,028 kilos value L.E. 25,969, a decrease in 1905 of 1,038,537 kilos, value L.E. 12,883.

div.head:
CYPRUS AGRICULTURE.
REPORTS FROM DISTRICTS
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
Nicosia, October 12.

The High Commissioner was bust at the end of last month visiting the chief villages of the wine producing localities in the Limassol district, The Director of Agriculture has also been visiting in the same neighborhood, en quiring into the nature and causes of various vine diseases. Reports from the Kyriena dis- tricot state that the carob crop, and also the olive oil yield, fall short of those of last year. Large quantities of gran have been conveyed by rail to Famagusta during the summer from the grain stores which have been established at different stations along the line. The existence of these stores has been of much assistance in effecting the delivery of tithe grain from the various scatters villages in that district.

div.head: PERSONAL NOTES
div.p: Sir J. Hutchinson (Chief Justice) and Lady Hutchinson arrived in Cypress by last mail from England after three months leave of absence. The Rev. and Mrs. CollieSmith have arrived and taken up their residence at the vicarage. The reverend gentleman has been appointed chaplain of the Anglican Church in Cyprus.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We regret to learn that Mr. Anthony, ina- lector in the Ministry of Finance, is suffering from a bad attack of Malta fever, and leaves Alexandria for the Tyrol on the 21st inst. Dr. Orme, medical anperintendent of the Port Said Government Hospital, is also very ill with the same fever. We wish both of these popular Government officials a complete and speedy recovery.
Ahmed Djellal-ed Din Pasha will return to Alexandria by the North German steamer leaving Marseilles on the 1st prix. The Pasha will stay here for some time and then proceed to Cairo.

Reuter's Agency states that the announce- meant of the death of Marshal Edhem Pasha which appeared in the London newspapers on October 7, was incorrect. It was another Edhem who died recently, not the well-known military commander who conducted the campaign against Greece in 1897. Marshal Edhem Pasha is quite well.
Mr. Joseph Offord, the well known Ecypalc- gist, is leaving Marseilled on the 10th Novem- ber for Alexandria in order to have two months archaeological research in Egypt.
Dr. Love is expected to arrive on Monday next by the N.D.L.S.S Schleswig.

div.p: HON. A. J. DAVEY'S REPORT.

Two reports will be presented to Judge Somerville Tuck, the jugs-commitments at 8 p.m. to-day at the Mixed Courts Cairo, by the experts appointed examine the situation of the Sucreries, viz, Sir Wm. Willcocks, Bou- other on Bey. and M. Sampsolo.

The following resume of the report of the Hon. A. J. Davey with reference to the pro- cedings of the company from his appoint- meant by decree of the Commercial Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Tribanals to the 15th inst. will no doubt be of interest to many of our readers- Du per au 19 Septembre 1905.

La caisse a verse anx Chemins de fer de l'Etat une facture de L.E 5,100, un depot de garantie de L.E. 500, et L.E. 643 pour nolia de Septembre; allé a envoye aux neinee L.E. 6,280 pour faire face a leurs palemcuta habi- tues; elle a paye L.E. 3900 pour frais d'schata et transports de sucres strangers destinée a la Raffinera, L.E. 9,583 a divers crediteurs (dout L.E. 5,423 a la Societe d'Irrigation) L.E. 8,769 pour faxtures arrives a échéance, et L.E. 715 pour frais generanx.

Lee pimenta suivants ont été opères par cheques: L.E. 3,999 a la Societe Egyptienne d'Irrigation, L.E. 511 a Rolo e Figli, L.E. 2.810 a Lambert et Ralli et L.E. 1,100 a MM. Casamata et Malagoli pour travaux effectues a Armant.

Les recettes de caisse pendant la meme period not consists en LE 16,367 encaise- ments d'efieta en portefeuille, L.E. 17,395 versements de clients, L.E. 1,725 paiements de débiteurs et L.E. 117 recettes diverses. Du 20 Septembre au 15 Octobre 1905

Grace une repartition raisonner de la Canne de la region du Canal Ibrahimieh, lea usines de Rodah et de Bibeh out pu etze fer- mers et, suivant toujours le principe de la plus stricte économie, une grande partie du person- bel de ces usines a été congradie et celui du siege social et des antres usines sensiblement reduit.

Voici quelles ont été les principales opera- rions de caisse et de banque durant cetta période: 1) expédition de L.E. 9420 aux diverses usines pour leurs paiements habituels 2) L.E. 10,450 versées aux chemins de fer pour nolis de Julliet et Aout, plus L.E. 5357 pour paiements an comptant de tons les transporta faits pour le compte de la Societe du 20 sep- timbre an 15 octobre. 3) L.E. 2035 versées pour un semestre de loyer des terres d'Etas et L.E. 3049 versees a MM Suares freres et Cie pour la première echearence du-loyer actual de Cheik Fadl. 4) La société a fair ouvrir par la National Bank of Egypt un credit de L.K. 1950 a son agency de Paris poor faire face a dee frais divers en Europa. 5) Il a été verse LE 870 appointements de septembre LE 129 indemnity de licenciement, L.E. 2662 factures arrivées a échéance, L.E. 1992 versements faits a divers employés creditaura et L.E. 257, frais généraux etc. 6) Il a été verse a la National Bank LE 3900 frais afferenta ans achats de sucres Java et L.E. 1000 a lagent de la Ste. a Sues pour frais occasionnes par les arrivages de sucres achetes a l'etranger. 7) Lee recettas out consiste en L.E. 20.563 yentes sucres, L.E. 35.314 encaissements d'effets, L.E. 906 comp- tes débiteurs et L.E. 396 divers.

Voici maintenant la liste dee principales opérations approuvées par les contrôleurs: 1) ouverture d'un crédit de $55.000 chez la National Bank pour schata de sucres Java; 2) projet de demande de crédit a la Natio- nap Bank pour funds de roulement de la prochaine campagne sucrière; 3) prévisions pour le paiement de la 5e semestriallite de la Daire Sanieh Sugar Corporation a faire le 24 octobre; 4) demande d'un délai au Gouvernement pour le paument de L. E. 6000 qui serait votre fair fin octobre pour droits d'octroyer les Raffanes; 5) Unification des comptes de basques pour l'ouverture a la- National Bank d'un compte courant spécial, qui est actuellement de L.E. 31,379.

Hier apres idi a 3 heures a en lieu ae tri- bunal mixte de ire instance du Caire la re- union des actionnaires de la Societe des Sucreries Raffinerie d'Egypte. Le tribunal e'tait oresude par M, Tuck. A cette audience les experts M. Fourneron bey et M. Sarappaolo ont présente leur report supplémentaire sur la situation des Sucreries. Les deux experts ont fait diligence ces quinze derniers jours et grâce a un travail acharne de nuit, ils ont pu arriver a terminer les quine pages de leur rapport, sans compter seins tableaux annexes donnant la- situation exakte des comptes. D'autre part, Sir William Willcocks a produit un rapport en an- gland que M G Legrand a été charge de traduire. Si nos informations sont exactes, cette note a été soumise hier matin seulement aux deux autres experts pour être communiquer au tri- bual l'apres-midi. La note de Sir William Willcocks conclut, attirait-on hier matin, a la responsibilite des administrateurs des Suere- ries Raffinerie.
Les obligataires français de la Societe des Sucreries out charge Me Saint Plancat de la defense de leurs intereta.

M Saint Plancat, qui retrers prockaine- meant d'Euripe era done l'avocat de l'Associa- fion nationale des obligataires français des Sucreries. Cette association comprend 3000 a 4000 porteurs de titres, ce qui représente en viron une quarantaine de millions de france. Le greffe commercial du Tribunal mixte a engistze le dept de pieces rectificative du bilan repose le 16 septembre denier en verts d'un process-verbal sineir conn:

"L'an 1905, le dimanobe 15 octobre, a 10 h. 1/2, an greffe commercial da Tribunal mixte du Cairs, par devant nous D. Chiariaoli, greffier, a comparu de Wiart, au nom et pour la compta de la Societe Gaoerale des Sucreries

et da la Raffinerie d'Egypte, poursuites et dili gences de l'an do ses admimstrateurs délégoé- tlio honorab'o A. J. D.wey, lcquer non* a d( claré quo lo bilan dépoté parle ncmparan ès qualités doit Otro modifié en suite do rei soignumouts parvenus au siègo social, ps lottro da 26 septembre 1905 émanant- de I Société Générale pour favoriser le commerce et l'industrie nationale do Paris ; qu'eu suite d cette lettre et du compte qu'elle transmittait le chef comptable do la Societe des Sucreriei a du changer certaines écritures ; qu'en conse- quence le comparant ès-qualités dépose entr nos mains les documents ci-après par lui paraphés.
1. Un feuillet simple do papier comptable grand format contenant les écritures figurant su bilan déposé et devant être annulées suivant lesdits lettres et comptes.

2. Un feuillet double do papier comptable graud format contenant dos écritures nouvelle modifiant le bilan déposé suivant los indien tions desdits lettres et comptes. La comparant nous a requis de dresser act du présent dépôt.
Dont acte :
(Signé) : MERZBACH-D. CHIARISOLI.

— Par ordonnance, rendue avent-hier par M le juge commissaire Tuck, l'honorable A. J Davey, administratour-détégué de la Sociéte des Sucreries, est autorisé a continuer les ope rations de vente de sucre candi que la Societe avait engagés avec le Comptoir Nationa d'Escompte de Paris.
L'ordonnance dit :

"Disons que l'autorisation de continuer son commerce implique pour la Société Général des Sucreries et de la Raffiuerie d'Egypte le droit de continuer avec le Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris ses relations habituelle consistant notsamment dans la vente do Candis par l'intormédiaire de ladite banque ; "Disons, partant, que l'administratear-délé gué, The honorable A. J. Davey, est autorisé recevoir toutes sommes qui peuvent être due à la Société, notamment le solde créditeur du par le Comptoir National de Paris et a en donner bonne et valable décharge daus le conditions spécifiées dans nos ordonnances des 20 et 26 septembre 1905."

div.head: Algésiras
div.p: Algésiras, écrit un journal de Parié, c'est la ville du jour, où va siéger la conférence mare caine ; Portsmouth est déja daus la pénombre de-l'oubli.

La ville où los diplomates européens vont si réunir est surtout célèbre par le brillant com- bat quo l'amiral français Linois soutint contre l'amiral anglais Saumarez, le 6 juillet 1801. Ce succès, qui rappelait les plus grands jours d, notre ancienne marine produisit on France un enthousiasme me général. Trois vaisseaux françai- combattireut contre six anglais; en détruisirent deux et sur les autres en gardèrent un prison- nier. La Prance battit des mains n ce bean lai d'armes et le premier Consul envoya un sabre d'honne .r au brave amiral Linois. Algésiras a une foire très pittoresque, "la féria", où l'on a un aperça for carachteristique ces mocars locales et où détient sous les cos- tumes les plus bigarrés, tous les types si varié de l'extreme Espagne.
Les diplomates suront sûrement le plaisir d'y assister. La féria ayant lieu tous les aus en juillet, la lenteur mystérieuse de la diplo matie saura bien faire traîner la Conféreuc jusques-la.

A moins que la conférence, malgré la décision prise, ne se réunisse pas à Algésiras. Les diplo- mates a ment ioura aises. Or, la petite ville espagnole est loin d'offrir, tant au point de vue des communications que des logements, le comfortable nécessaire. Dans ce cas, Algésira n'aura ou qu'une résurrection éphémère, assez cependant pour nous remettre en mémoire un glories fait d'armes français.

div.head: THE CQTTON MARKET
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's WeeklyReport.
Liverpool, October 12.

Egyptian Cotton is very neglected, the actual sales of ''Spot being very small ; there haS been scarcely sufficient busi- ness doing to test prices and quotations are without change for the week. Futures have been inactive, and the follow- ing are the latest values .
Oot 7.24 Dec. 7.6 Feb. 7.1 Nov. 7.14 Jan. 7.2 Mar. 7.0

American Futures. The beginning of the week was characterized by heavy "Bear" selling; everything apparently being in favor of a tall, and prices declined rapidly 23 points, but towards the dose of the week the Market was freely applied with "killing frost" cables, ceasing a sharp reaction take place, but whether any serious damage has occurred seems doubtful. Spinners have bought "Spot" cotton much more freely, and the offerings of cif cotton by the South have been less plentiful, which has helped to strengthen the hands of the , "Bulls." This afternoon the Now York market report coming lower, thus indicating no material damage to the crop by frost our Market developed con- siderable weakness, and the following closing quotations shew a decline of 21 points for the week:—
Oct. 5.20 Jan./Fob. 5.31 May/June 5.40 Oct./Nov. 5.2 Feb./Mar. 5.33 Jun3/July 5.42 Nov./Dec. 5.24 Mar./Apr. 5.36 July/Aug. 5.43 Dec /Jan. 5.28 Apr./May 5.38.

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: COMPANY ROYAL INNISKILLINGS
MOUNTED INFANTRY.

The above teams met on Friday evening at Abbaasieh in a friendly encounter. The ground was in the pink of condition while both teams pot on their best available eleven, so every- thing pointed to a good gone. There would be about 500 spectators present when the ; teams lined out under the control of referee Mr. Spence in the following order : F Com pany—goal, Johnston ; backs, Duffy and Gabbrieth ; halves, Branagh, Bond, and Harbinson ; forwards. Boy Walib, Bradshaw Collins, Smyth, and Boy Armstrong. Mounted Infantry —goal, Clarke ; backs, Baggley and Williamson ; halves, Connelly, Goslin, and Skimmer ; forwards, Flagg, Dovey, Wolsam, Greer, and Gorman.

Collins started operations for F Company, Who took op the running, Smyth and Arm strong combining wall, but Williamson averted disaster. For almost ten minutes play re mained in this M. I. camp until a nice bit of manuveriog on the past of Greer and German ended in the latter having a shot which miseed the spot by inches. The greens now worked up ; Smyth, getting possession of the sphere, raced the length of the field and., centered, and WaLsh catching the ball, lost a glorious chance by sending behind. The mounted boys now had an innings, Greer and the centre forward showing conspicuous form ; the former's swinging centres went a-begging spring to the right wing not being in their place. Play was now confined to midfield until Bond relieved matters; only fora moment ' however, as the I Konnas came down once more. Their progress however was short-lived as Daffy with a great drive sent them to this right-about. The first inner of the match to the visitors, but this was sent behind. On the kick-off the M. I. took play in hand and Johnston had his hands fall, but be was equal to the occasion. Both trams were playing for all they were worth, both end being visited turn. Up and down the field they raced, tho pace boing a ' cracker." The galloping 8th ' were in a very favorable position when a free was given against Connelly. This was well placed into goal by Harbinson, a corner follow- ing this, and, being taken by Walsh, proved unproductive. Both teams strove hard to open the score, but all to no purpose. Some good play by Bond reulted in Armstrong getting the sphere and dodging a couple of opponents, sent across to Smyth, who in torn gave to Collins, who missed the mat h-wanted spot by inches. The Greens now held tho advantage, tho mounted boys' defences being severely taxed, and it took the custodian to be in hit best form or a sxore would have reunited. The M. I. now got away, Greer loading the group but Harbinson spoiled their little game and play was in a trice transferred, when William- Son and company came in fir a lively time. They however kept their goal intact At this stage of the game the excitement was great. Play raged fast and furious from this to half- time, the score then standing Mounted Infantry............. Nil F Company. ............. Nil.

After the usual interval and refreshments play was once more resumed. F Company soon swept around the Reds' goal, but the custodian saved in good style and play was token towards Johnstone, but the latter did not exert himself as the defense in front of him repelled all attacks. Some good individual play on the part of Harbinson ended in Walsh running the ball over the line. Play was now of the give-snd take order until Greer raised the hopes of his supporters by running the leather well np and entering well. Branagh, however, robbed Flag as Johnny was in the act of shooting. The green-shirts now took up the running sturdily, little Bond making good headway and parting to Smyth, who ran through all opposition and with an Unsaleable shot drew first blood for bis side. This made the. I Konvas play np mu-h better, and Gorman should have made the scores equal,' but over-eagerness spoiled a good chance. Both teams were playing with great determination, especially the Gallopers, who showed good form. The spectators now urged their favorites to go in and win, each end being visited in tarn, bat the shots either lacked the necessary sting or over-eagerness spoiled all attempts. A fine com- bined movement on the part of Smyth ended in Collins getting possession of the ball and with a "daisy cutter" be sent np the second goal on play. P Company deserved their lead. In resuming the Greens came away again and were within an ace of scoring, the custodian saving from Armstrong at the expense of a corner. This, however, came to nothing. The Gallopers now pulled themselves together and Green gave a Flag a glorious chance ; in fact, this chance of a lifetime, but his shot went the way of the others. The M.I. still kept that pressure up, but all to no avail, as Duffy and company were display Ing their cool form. P Company were now displaying some of last seasons form, Smyth Bond, and Collins proving themselves a terror to the Reds' defense. Play slackened down now until a rash was made on the Gallopers' citadel, a scrimmage ensuing. The custodian saved well, but be had to acknow- Ledge defeat a third time. With a good lead F Company took things pretty easy now. This horse soldier* were advancing in strong order, leading the column, when the long whistle sounded full time, leaving F Company winners of a most interesting and well fought match by the following (core : F. Company ... .............. 8 Goals Mounted Infantry............. Nil Mr. I. Spence refereed to the satisfaction of all concerned.

div.head: GAMBLING IN COTON.
div.p: The publication of the foil official report of he second International Cotton Congress, held a Jane last, together with a ootering circular rom the President, Mr. Micara, serves to remind os that a great step has been taken n the direction of'organising the industry >oth in first Britain and on the Continent, tod to some rxtent in the United States. The >bject of this organisation is, in the first piaoe, :o afford protection against gambling; in the isoond, to extend the socrces of the supply of -aw cotton; and, thirdly, to introdnoe desir- tble reforms in the oondnot of the industry as i whole, and in the packing, delivery and her details connected with the famishing of to raw material. \With the energetio efforts hat are now being'tnsde to extend the growth 5f cotton within trig. British Empire, as set forth in Mr. J. H, Hatton's admirable paper -ead at the Conferees, we dealt folly at the rime, and we need only repeat here that the Bri-ish Cotton Crowing Association is doing nost excellent work in this direction, the effect of which it may be reasonably hoped will in i tew years be to render Europe considerably less dependent npon American cotton than is the case at present. This Association, however, and the other Associations ol the same kind in the Continent are distinot from the Inter- lational Federation,1 though they are olosely inked with it, and in course of timaLwill i.rohab'y be affiliated thereto. Theobj«ji» of :ho Federation are, however, ajwajhafrwseen, noro comprehensive, the most prominent, per- reps, being in the words (if fir.jMstna:— To counteract the optwations of mani- pulators in unduly enKneing tbe-prioe of the raw material, making it a counter in gambling operations; indeed, an effective remedy for these operations can only he attained by international action on the part of the users of ootton.

Mr. Macara nsefally reminds ns, that the recent wages dispute in the English ootton trade, which almost led to a national calamity, was mainly brought about by the said gambling operations. He adds an illustration of the Bnormous losses to the industry which may be and are caused by such speculation. The annual average crop of the world, at a value of 5d per lb, realises some £160,000,000, and the estimated value of the products manufactur- sd therefrom is £350,000,000. An average price of 4d per lb would, it is stated, prove sufficiently remunerative to growers, even ia reasons of comparatively poor yield. In the reason before last, however, speculation raised the average price paid by spinners to as muoh as 7d per lb—' in round figures about £100,000,000 in exoesa of a prioe which would have adequately rewarded the growers for their labour and enterprise.''

A large proportion of this enormous sum went into the poskets of oatside speculators in no way connected with the industry, and it is not surprising, nnder such circumstances, that the manufacturers of Barope are sink- ing international jealousies and differences and cimbining for their mutual protection. Bven the Amerioan manufacturers, as judged by the recent speech of Mr. J. R. MaoColl, the President of the New England Cotton Manufacturers' Association, are (ailing into line with the rest, and an American delegate was, as a matter of fact, present at the June Conference ; although, as that gentleman re- marked, American spinners may not have yet reached the point where they are prepared to organise to rastriot the consumption of Ameri can ootton. The difficulties in the way of patting a curb on exosssive speculation were reoognised—although perhaps not folly reoog- nised—by the Congress. It was admitted that business in lutores is neoessary for the market as at present constituted, and also -that men cannot handle enormous crops properly unless ibey obtain some cover. Sufficient oover is not to be found in the trade itself, and so the outside speculator is drawn into the market, and manipulation interferes disastrous- ly with the play of supply and demand. It is suggested that if every mill included in the international Federation .were to take over a oertain amonot ot ootton—say, even a quarter of a million bales in a'l—they might. be safe- guarded against the worst evils ol manipula- tion. The regulation of the output, which might also to some extent be secured, would . afford furtherproteotion; and to hedged round, the ootton market would present a less at- tractive field for gambling to the profes- sional speculator than is the case at present. Obviously there are very considerable difficul- ties in the way of attaining this desirable end, but the first step is to obtain the adhesion to the Federation of the majority of Boropean producers, and this seems in a fair way of being attained. It is intolerab's that an enormous, indispensable industry, employing hundreds of thousands of operatives, shoold be muloted to the extent of a hundred millions sterling in a single year through the operations of pro- fessional gamblers. Everyone, therefore, who is interested in the welfare of the working classes, or who is desirous of upholding the pricoiple of fair play in commerce, will wish God-speed to the International Federation, and to the various cotton growing associations which are striving to place the industry on a sounder Economic basis.
